content.user_title: Generate Table of Contents for Markdown
content.value_statement: Manually creating and updating Table of Contents in markdown files is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill automatically generates and updates TOCs by parsing headers, supporting batch processing, configurable depth levels, and smart insertion modes.
actual_capabilities: Generate TOC for single or multiple markdown files
Process files using glob patterns and recursive search
Configure header depth levels (min and max H1-H6)
Insert TOC with three modes: auto, top, or marker
Preview changes with dry-run before applying
limitations: Only supports markdown files with standard header syntax
Cannot process files with non-standard header formats
Requires Python 3 with no external dependencies
Anchor generation follows GitHub style only

use_cases.title: Update all project documentation
use_cases.description: Generate a complete table of contents for all markdown files in a project repository. Perfect for maintaining consistent navigation across large documentation sets.

use_cases.title: Create README navigation
use_cases.description: Add a clean table of contents to project README files. Helps users quickly navigate to relevant sections without scrolling through entire documents.

use_cases.title: Standardize documentation markers
use_cases.description: Add consistent TOC markers across multiple documentation files. Ensures uniform structure when building multi-page documentation guides.

prompt_templates.title: Generate basic TOC
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a table of contents for README.md with headers H2 and H3.

prompt_templates.title: Batch process with preview
prompt_templates.prompt: Preview the TOC changes without applying them.

prompt_templates.title: Recursive documentation update
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a table of contents for all markdown files in the docs/ directory recursively.

prompt_templates.title: Custom header levels
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a TOC with only H2 headers for the contributing guide, and H2-H4 for the main README.
prompt_templates.scenario: Different TOC depths for different files

best_practices: Always use --dry-run first to preview changes before applying them
Use --insert marker mode for precise TOC placement in complex documents
Set appropriate --max-level to avoid overly detailed TOCs in large files
anti_patterns: Running without preview on important documentation files
Using deep header levels that create excessively long TOCs
Forgetting to update TOCs after restructuring documentation

faq.question: What header levels are included by default?
faq.answer: By default, the TOC includes H2 and H3 headers. Use --min-level and --max-level to customize this range.

faq.question: Can I generate a TOC without modifying the file?
faq.answer: Yes, use --dry-run to preview the TOC without applying any changes to the file.

faq.question: How does the auto insertion mode work?
faq.answer: Auto mode searches for existing TOC sections first, then YAML frontmatter, then the first header, or inserts at the top of the file.

faq.question: Can I process multiple files at once?
faq.answer: Yes, pass multiple file paths, use glob patterns like docs/*.md, or use --recursive to process all markdown files in a directory tree.

faq.question: What anchor format is generated?
faq.answer: The script generates GitHub-compatible anchors: lowercase, spaces to hyphens, special characters removed, multiple hyphens collapsed.

faq.question: Is the script portable to other projects?
faq.answer: Yes, the script has no hardcoded paths and works with any markdown file. You can copy it to any project.
